description: An Italian restaurant with a Caprese influence, omakase in Chinatown, and more restaurant news.
content: Replacing the opulent Del Posto, this newcomer offers a different style of grandeur and a distinctive approach to fine dining in New York. Though it retains the general contours of its predecessor, it’s more plush and richly upholstered, in deep browns with bright accents. In the evenings, there is live music, including singing from a new balcony stage over the bar, now relocated to a more central position. “It has a combination of luxury elements; it’s built for celebratory moments,” said Jeff Katz, who owns Al Coro with the chef, Melissa Rodriguez.  (She is also the chef and a partner at Mel’s.) Mr. Katz and James Kent, his business partner, recently divided their holdings amicably: Mr. Katz now runs Al Coro and Mel’s, the pizzeria next door, and Mr. Kent is in charge of the Lower Manhattan properties Crown Shy, Saga and Overstory. Mr. Kent said the split made sense from a geographical standpoint. Ms. Rodriguez, who started at Del Posto over 10 years ago and became the executive chef in 2017, described the food as regional Italian. But her tasting dinners ($195 for five courses, $245 for seven), which are detailed by the servers, not printed, involve Italy sporadically. Gremolata and lardo adorn green and white asparagus; frico tops vegetable giardiniera; and a pasta course features culurgiones, a type of dumpling filled with potato, Fontina and mascarpone, with a caviar butter sauce and razor clams. A main course might be a whole roasted sea bass with Marsala and mushrooms, chicken breast done in the style of Peking duck or both on the seven-course menu. Many courses include a collection of savory condiments. The plan is for the menus to be sent to diners the day after their visit, and Ms. Rodriguez plans to change the lineup monthly. There will be a cocktail bar on the spacious lower level. (Opens Wednesday)

The principal languages in Belarus, which was part of the Russian Empire and then the Soviet Union, and which remains in Russia’s grip, are Russian and Belarusian. Russian is the language of power, cities and empire; Belarusian is the language of the countryside, the home, the nation. In neighboring Ukraine, whose history in some ways resembles that of Belarus, Ukrainian is now the primary language. Belarusian, meanwhile, is classified by UNESCO as “vulnerable.”

description: A financial executive and sometime sports entrepreneur, he was thwarted in his quixotic quest to help homeowners with underwater mortgages during the Great Recession.
content: Steven Gluckstern, a wide-ranging financial executive and sometime sports entrepreneur whose quixotic plan to offer relief to struggling homeowners in the aftermath of the Great Recession was thwarted by the banking and real estate industries, died on May 29 at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Granada Nights’ Review: Growing Abroad
description: This drama tells the hackneyed story of a lovelorn expatriate pulling himself together and dragging us around with him.
content: It doesn’t take long in “Granada Nights” before someone is sagely explaining the difference between a tourist and a traveler. A peevish university grad, Ben (Antonio Aakeel), is on the receiving end of this hoary conversation-starter, but he’s a bit distracted. He has journeyed from London to Granada, Spain, to surprise his girlfriend at her doorstep — something that people in movies should really avoid doing. When he realizes it’s over, what follows is a hackneyed story of a tedious, lovelorn expatriate, pulling himself together and dragging us around with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: The Government Set a Colossal Wildfire. What Are Victims Owed?
description: Two prescribed burns got out of control, becoming New Mexico’s largest recorded wildfire. But despite the backlash, experts say it’s necessary to thin forests in a region primed for destruction.
content: MORA, N.M. — It started small, with a team of federal employees using drip torches to ignite a prescribed burn in the Santa Fe National Forest, aimed at thinning out dense pine woodlands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: Here are 4 takeaways from Tuesday’s Jan. 6 hearing.
description: The hearing by the House committee investigating the Capitol attack showed how President Donald J. Trump and his allies applied pressure to state officials to overturn the election results.
content: The fourth hearing held by the House committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol focused on the elaborate efforts by President Donald J. Trump and his allies to hijack one of the foundations of democracy: the process behind the peaceful transfer of power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: The Wartime Celebrity Leader
description: A Times correspondent in Kyiv discusses President Volodymyr Zelensky.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett and Andrew Jacobs
title: F.D.A. Aims to Cut Down on Smoking by Slashing Nicotine Levels in Cigarettes
description: The move would be an effort to further wean Americans from addictive tobacco products and reduce smoking-related illnesses.
content: The Food and Drug Administration is planning to require tobacco companies to slash the amount of nicotine in traditional cigarettes to make them less addictive and reduce the toll of smoking that claims 480,000 lives each year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: These Spiced, Marinated Yogurt Balls Are Perfect for Snacking
description: Called Pariva, they come soaked in seasoned oil and are worth eating as is, spread on crackers or afloat in cold soups.
content: Just when you might have run out of ideas for something to toothpick alongside a drink, here comes Pariva: yogurt in a munchable format. Manjarrie Saha, a native of Kolkata who came to the United States to study and had a career in financial services, has introduced yogurt balls soaked in seasoned oil. She started making them in Boston in 2019, calling them YogiBalls but renamed them with a word derived from the Hindi word for transformation (Parivartan). Pariva are tasty and come with tandoori seasoning, za’atar and, my favorite, rosemary and garlic. Serve them as is or spread them on crackers, on cucumber slices, afloat in a cold soup or in salads. Stuff cherry tomatoes or figs with them. The flavored oils they leave behind can be put to use in salads and so forth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning and Noam Scheiber
title: Drivers’ Lawsuit Claims Uber and Lyft Violate Antitrust Laws
description: They accuse the companies of depriving them of employee benefits while also denying them the freedoms of independent contractors.
content: A group of drivers claimed on Tuesday that Uber and Lyft are engaging in anticompetitive practices by setting the prices customers pay and limiting drivers’ ability to choose which rides they accept without penalty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: New Soho Rep Season Spotlights Emerging Artists
description: A Bengali-English play and a meditation on the work of Whitney Houston are among the offerings.
content: Soho Rep, a 65-seat Off Off Broadway theater in Lower Manhattan, has always been a home for experimental, formally inventive work. But a play in its new season is beyond anything one of the company’s three directors, Meropi Peponides, ever thought it would be able to support: A Bengali-English play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: Deshaun Watson Settles 20 of the 24 Sexual Misconduct Cases Against Him
description: The lawyer for the 24 women announced the agreements but did not disclose details. The plaintiffs had accused Watson of coercive behavior and sexual misconduct during massages.
content: Deshaun Watson, the Cleveland Browns quarterback, has reached settlements with 20 of the 24 women who have filed sexual misconduct lawsuits against him, the lawyer Tony Buzbee announced Tuesday morning. In a statement, Buzbee, who represents Watson’s accusers, said that the terms and amounts of the settlements were confidential and that those cases would be dismissed once finalized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Paella in a Can? If You Have the Proper Pan.
description: A new paella kit from a chef in Valencia comes in seafood and vegetarian versions, to be added to rice to serve three or four.
content: A new paella kit made in Spain has hit the shelves at Despaña Brand Foods, a retail and wholesale source for Spanish foods. It consists of a can of enough seasoned seafood broth with some bits of seafood to serve three or four with precisely measured rice. The proper paella pan, at 34 centimeters (13 ½ inches), is $20; a skillet that size can be used. The kit is from a company affiliated with the chef Rafa Margós, in Valencia; he prepares the broth ingredients traditionally over a wood fire. With the step-by-step instructions and a pinch of salt you get a fine, though simple, pan of paella rice. (A vegetarian version with a rich vegetal broth is also available.) Tuck your own additions — shrimp, diced piquillo peppers, artichoke hearts — into the rice as it cooks to enhance things. If you cannot use a wood-fired grill, then a gas or even electric stove will do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: S​outh Korea Launches Satellite With Its Own Rocket for the First Time
description: The launch brings the country closer to its ambition of becoming a player in the space industry, no longer reliant on technology from other countries.
content: SEOUL — South Korea said it successfully launched a small but working satellite into orbit using its first homemade rocket on ​Tuesday, bringing the country closer to its dream of becoming a new player in the space industry and deploying its own spy satellites to better monitor North Korea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Annie Karni
title: Bipartisan Gun Bill Clears Initial Vote in Senate
description: The 64-to-34 vote came just hours after Republicans and Democrats released the text of the legislation, which could become the most significant overhaul of the nation’s gun laws in decades.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Tuesday cleared the first hurdle to passing a bipartisan measure aimed at keeping firearms out of the hands of dangerous people, agreeing to take up a compromise bill whose enactment would break a yearslong stalemate over federal legislation to address gun violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Head of State Police Calls Response to Uvalde Shooting an ‘Abject Failure’
description: The director of the Department of Public Safety said that police officers wasted time looking for a classroom door key that was “never needed.”
content: AUSTIN, Texas — The head of the Texas State Police on Tuesday offered a pointed and emphatic rebuke of the police response to a shooting last month at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, calling it “an abject failure” that ran counter to decades of training.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: Microsoft Plans to Eliminate Face Analysis Tools in Push for ‘Responsible A.I.’
description: The technology giant will stop offering automated tools that predict a person’s gender, age and emotional state and will restrict the use of its facial recognition tool.
content: For years, activists and academics have been raising concerns that facial analysis software that claims to be able to identify a person’s age, gender and emotional state can be biased, unreliable or invasive — and shouldn’t be sold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz
title: Can Natural Gas Be Used to Create Power With Fewer Emissions?
description: One company says it has the technology. And though investors looking for cleaner power generation are lining up, some environmentalists are skeptical.
content: This article is part of Upstart, a series about young companies harnessing new science and technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Air Force Detains Airman in Attack on U.S. Base in Syria
description: The April attack at the Green Village base in northeastern Syria wounded four American service members.
content: WASHINGTON — The Air Force has detained a U.S. service member in connection with an attack in April at a small American military base in northeastern Syria that wounded four U.S. troops, the service said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Johnny Diaz
title: Wildfire in New Jersey Could Become the State’s Largest in Years
description: The Mullica River fire in Wharton State Forest in South Jersey has burned about 13,500 acres. Officials said it may have been started by an illegal campfire.
content: A fast-moving wildfire in a remote section of a state forest in New Jersey was threatening to become the state’s largest fire in 15 years, and may have been started by an illegal campfire, officials said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: A Three-Stop Bakery Crawl in the East Village
description: These bakeries all offer their own unique delights.
content: New York City’s top-tier walkability has always made it a perfect place for a crawl — to bars, galleries, “Sex and the City” filming sites. There are so few places that can’t be reached by foot. (Governors Island footbridge when?)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Korsha Wilson
title: The Black Oysterman Taking Half Shells From the Bar to the Block
description: The Brooklyn man behind the Real Mother Shuckers wants to return oysters to ubiquity in New York City and honor the legacy of Black oystermen.
content: On a recent afternoon in Brooklyn, a man known as Moody stood behind his dark blue cart in front of the Bushwick location of BK Lobster, gingerly prying open Fanny Bay, bluepoint and Prince Edward Island oysters with his shucking knife and presenting them to customers on a bed of ice. Occasionally, a curious passer-by would ask him what he was doing, to which he replied, “Selling oysters,” raising his voice loud enough to be heard over the rumble of the J train overhead and the hip-hop music playing from a portable speaker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Painful Path
description: The government’s plan to fight inflation could cost jobs and restrict wage growth.
content: Americans’ household finances are headed for a rough patch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘The Story Won’t Die’ Review: Art in a Time of Crisis
description: This documentary about Syrian refugee artists explores the role of art in the face of war and displacement.
content: In 1949, the German philosopher Theodor Adorno famously declared that to write poetry after Auschwitz was “barbaric.” The question underpinning his statement remains ever relevant: In the face of wars, genocides and other atrocities, does art-making serve any purpose? David Henry Gerson’s documentary, “The Story Won’t Die,” answers with a resounding yes. The Syrian refugee artists profiled in the film — men and women who’ve suffered one of the most brutal displacements of our time — make a case not just for art’s survival but for art as a means of survival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brenda Shaughnessy
title: Asking the Hard Questions About Motherhood
description: Anna Hogeland’s debut novel, “The Long Answer,” grapples with the many forms motherhood takes, and doesn’t take.
content: The question keeping many women awake at night right now is whether our government will revoke or uphold our right to control and choose our reproductive destinies. For 50 years the law has recognized women’s bodies as private, and women’s lives as our own, and now the right to choose our own fate is endangered. What’s wrong with this? That’s the question this debut novel poses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Grilling Tools That Will Last Much Longer Than One Summer
description: From Food52, the set by Schmidt Brothers Cutlery is safely long-handled and made from high-carbon stainless steel.
content: A new set of four utensils for the outdoor grill, all neatly packed in a wooden box, is a summer essential for owning or gifting. From Food52, this set is safely long-handled and made from high-carbon stainless steel, with a spatula, fork, sturdy tongs and a basting brush with a conveniently angled head. They’re by Jared and Jordan Schmidt of Schmidt Brothers Cutlery in New York. The company also makes a practical grill brush with three interchangeable scrubbers to get the grates ready for the next batch of burgers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Tannenbaum
title: George Michael Preferred Music to Fame. The Doc He Made Does, Too.
description: “George Michael: Freedom Uncut,” a film the musician worked on with his longtime collaborator David Austin, tells the story of his professional life via interviews and previously unseen footage.
content: George Michael and David Austin were best friends who met because their mothers were best friends. Austin’s family lived at 67 Redhill Drive in the working class East Finchley area of North London, and Michael’s family was at 57. The two wrote songs together and remained close even as one became a global superstar and the other didn’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Hamilton
title: Between Fathers and Daughters, It’s Complicated. This Book Probes Why.
description: Katherine Angel’s essay collection “Daddy Issues” examines our often prurient fascination with the dynamic, and that fascination’s inherent misogyny.
content: It’s not that I want to date my dad, I just want him to want to date me. He thinks I’m the most beautiful girl in the world. He also told me, when I was 15, that I’d never have a boyfriend who wouldn’t cheat on me. If I cheated first? “Deny! Deny! Deny!” advised my dad, and I listened because he kind of reminded me of Winston Churchill when he slammed his hand down on the table like that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Citing a disastrous pandemic response, an expert panel calls for an overhaul of the U.S. public health system.
description: The panel recommends that a new federal position be created to oversee public health.
content: A bipartisan panel of health experts calls on Tuesday for an overhaul of the American public health system that would greatly expand the role of the federal government, giving Washington the authority to set minimum health standards and coordinate a patchwork of nearly 3,000 state, local and tribal agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: As Koepka Leaves for LIV Golf, the PGA Tour Mulls Changes
description: Brooks Koepka, a four-time major winner, and another top-20 player committed to the new series Tuesday. In a players’ meeting, the PGA Tour commissioner outlined tweaks that included a revised schedule.
content: Since March, Brooks Koepka has emphatically denied he would consider joining the breakaway, Saudi-backed LIV Golf series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Gabriel Sterling: a Georgia elections official who pushed back on Trump’s false fraud claims.
description: Unlike other officials who did not act on the former president’s falsehoods, Mr. Sterling spoke out repeatedly against them.
content: Gabriel Sterling, a top election official in Georgia who publicly disputed former President Donald J. Trump’s false claims of election fraud in the 2020 election, is testifying before the Jan. 6 committee on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sherry Turkle
title: Building Back Better — One Community at a Time
description: Michelle Wilde Anderson’s “The Fight to Save the Town” highlights four places where citizens have come together to combat urban decline.
content: THE FIGHT TO SAVE THE TOWNReimagining Discarded AmericaBy Michelle Wilde Anderson
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ferran Adrià
title: What Nourishes the Soul
description: The question of reality sends one of the world’s most innovative chefs back to the kitchen to ponder what it means to eat well.
content: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What is reality? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Bee Nguyen wins the Democratic nomination for secretary of state in Georgia.
description: Ms. Nguyen, a Democratic state representative, will face off in November against Brad Raffensperger, the Republican incumbent, who resisted Donald Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election.
content: ATLANTA — Bee Nguyen, a Democratic state representative, has won the party’s nomination for Georgia secretary of state, setting up a closely watched race for an office that served as a bulwark against former President Donald J. Trump’s attempt to subvert the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Many parents in the U.S. have tough questions about the vaccines for young children.
description: It’s a moment many parents have anxiously awaited for months: Children younger than age 5 are now eligible for vaccination against the coronavirus, among the last Americans to qualify.
content: It’s a moment many parents have anxiously awaited for months: Children younger than age 5 are now eligible for vaccination against the coronavirus, among the last Americans to qualify.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Genevieve Glatsky
title: He Promised to Transform Colombia as President. Can He Fulfill That Vow?
description: During his campaign, Gustavo Petro proposed major reforms if he was elected. After winning Sunday’s presidential election, he’ll now have to prove he can carry out those changes.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — In a packed arena in Bogotá on Sunday, amid a burst of confetti and below a sign that read “Colombia won,” Gustavo Petro celebrated his victory as the first leftist ever elected president of Colombia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levy
title: In the Scramble for a Campsite, Everyone Deserves an Equal Chance
description: A booking system used by the National Park Service may be disadvantaging  marginalized communities the service has worked hard to attract.
content: In the summer darkness of a July night in 2016, I was stumbling bleary-eyed toward the kiosk at the entrance to Camp 4, the campground in Yosemite National Park favored by climbers worldwide, when I tripped on something.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Eshe Nelson
title: U.K. Train Strike Brings Transit Chaos
description: Travel was disrupted for tens of millions of people during the country’s biggest walkout in decades as union leaders warned of a summer of labor unrest.
content: LONDON — Britain was hobbled on Tuesday by its largest railway strike in three decades, halting trains across the country, throwing travel plans for tens of millions of Britons and visitors into chaos, and setting off what union and government leaders warned could be a long summer of labor unrest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: ‘I took an oath,’ Rusty Bowers, the Arizona House speaker, says of rejecting efforts to overturn the election.
description: Mr. Bowers’s refusal to bend to pressure from Donald J. Trump and his allies led to harassment outside his home in which he was called a “pedophile” and other epithets.
content: Over nearly an hour, Rusty Bowers, a Republican who is the speaker of the House of Representatives in Arizona, testified on Tuesday in painstaking and emotional detail about the pressure campaign he faced over several weeks after the Nov. 3, 2020, election, in which President Donald J. Trump lost the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah B. Solomon
title: Yellen may soon get her name on the greenback.
description: While the Treasury secretary sat for her official currency signing more than a year ago, under arcane rules her signature has not yet appeared on the U.S. dollar.
content: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen moved one step closer to finally getting her signature on the U.S. dollar on Tuesday, when President Biden named Marilynn Malerba as treasurer of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: Gavin Newsom Pokes the G.O.P. Bear
description: The California governor is up to something as he bashes Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis and even his fellow Democrats. Just what, exactly, is a hot topic of discussion on the left.
content: Gavin Newsom keeps picking exactly the kinds of fights that presidential candidates like to pick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: South Dakota Removes Its Attorney General After Fatal Crash
description: Jason Ravnsborg, who killed a man with his car in 2020, was removed from office after the State Senate voted to convict him. He was impeached by the House in April.
content: The South Dakota Senate voted to remove the state’s attorney general, Jason Ravnsborg, from office on Tuesday evening in an impeachment trial after Mr. Ravnsborg fatally struck a man with his car in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Ice Cream Sandwiches Engineered by Food Names
description: You can order the desserts from the Musket Room, which is collaborating with chefs like JJ Johnson and Stefano Secchi and other food world personalities.
content: This is more complicated than running for the local Mister Softee truck, but also much more rewarding. Plan ahead and order ice cream sandwiches online from the Musket Room in NoLIta for pickup on Saturdays starting at 12:30 p.m. They offered the sandwiches last summer, but there’s a new twist: Each week’s offering, through the end of August, will be created in collaboration with a chef, bartender or food industry personality invited by the executive pastry chef, Camari Mick. This week it’s JJ Johnson of Fieldtrip, whose ice cream is inspired by jollof rice, with macaron cookies and popped rice. Next week will be Rezdora’s turn with Stefano Secchi’s brown butter truffle and ricotta ice creams between amaretto cookies. And so on throughout the summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim, Clifford Krauss and Anton Troianovski
title: Western Move to Choke Russia’s Oil Exports Boomerangs, for Now
description: With China and India buying the Russian oil shunned by the West in an effort to force an end to the Ukraine invasion, Moscow is earning more now than it did before the war.
content: SEOUL — When the United States and European Union moved to curtail purchases of Russian fossil fuels this year, they hoped it would help make the Russian invasion of Ukraine so economically painful for Moscow that President Vladimir V. Putin would be forced to abandon it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Tony-Winning ‘Company’ Revival Will End Broadway Run July 31
description: Despite picking up 5 prizes at this month’s Tony Awards, the Sondheim-blessed revival was facing a tough summer at the box office.
content: A Tony-winning, gender-swapped, Sondheim-blessed revival of “Company” will end its Broadway run on July 31.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley and Lauren Herstik
title: What did Judy Huth say happened at the Playboy Mansion?
description: She accused Mr. Cosby of sexually assaulting her at the Playboy Mansion in 1975 when she was 16.
content: Judy Huth, who is now 64, and a friend, Donna Samuelson, testified that in 1975 when they were teenagers they were invited by Mr. Cosby to join him at the Playboy Mansion in Los Angeles several days after meeting him on a film set in a park near their homes, where he was making a film, “Let’s Do It Again.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley, Lauren Herstik and Douglas Morino
title: A verdict in the Bill Cosby civil trial has been reached. Here’s what to know.
description: The jury has reached a verdict in the civil case filed by a California woman who accused Bill Cosby of sexually assaulting her when she was a teenager, the court announced Tuesday.
content: The jury has reached a verdict in the civil case filed by a California woman who accused Bill Cosby of sexually assaulting her when she was a teenager, the court announced Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah B. Solomon
title: Millions of tax returns have not been processed as the I.R.S. tries to clear its backlog.
description: The agency started the tax season with more than eight million unfinished returns from the previous year.
content: Millions of 2021 taxpayer returns filed with the Internal Revenue Service have yet to be completed, and the agency is facing a larger-than-normal backlog at this point in the tax season, the Treasury Department said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Alexander
title: Indoor Farming Is a ‘No-Brainer.’ Except for the Carbon Footprint.
description: Why greenhouses might be the future of vegetable agriculture.
content: It’s shaping up to be a tough year for agriculture: With record drought gripping the West, farmers in California’s Central Valley are leaving vast tracts of fertile land unplanted. A January cold snap in Florida devastated tomato crops there, leaving the survivors vulnerable to disease. Two months later, an unusually hard freeze in the Carolinas left some farmers with little to no strawberries and blueberries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: The panel issued a subpoena for footage from the White House during the Capitol attack.
description: A British filmmaker, Alex Holder, said he had complied with the subpoena and would also be deposed by the committee’s staff.
content: Even as the Jan. 6 committee holds its fourth public hearing concerning the attack on the Capitol, it has continued to investigate the events surrounding the assault, recently issuing a subpoena to a British filmmaker for footage taken inside the White House as it was unfolding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: ‘Stories of Japanese Tea’ Is a Guide for the Novice and Expert Alike
description: This easygoing handbook that examines just about every aspect of Japanese tea and provides recipes for tea-based food and cocktails.
content: As he tells it in his new book, “Stories of Japanese Tea,” Zach Mangan, a musician turned tea expert, first encountered fine Japanese tea in Paris. He went on to work for Ito En, a Japanese tea company in New York, then moved to Japan and established his tea company in Fukuoka Prefecture in southern Japan. After attracting clients like the chef David Bouley, Mr. Mangan began exporting teas and utensils to New York and now, with his wife, Minami Mangan, who is from Kanagawa Prefecture, owns Kettl, a serene teahouse with its flagship in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and a location on the Bowery. His extensive but easygoing handbook patiently takes the novice and the expert through just about every aspect of Japanese tea. He defines categories (the cha-cha-cha of sencha, matcha, bancha and so forth), interviews growers, brings the landscape to life, discusses the basics and subtleties of how to brew and includes recipes for tea-based food and cocktails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: How New York Got a Glorious Throwback Roller-Skating Extravaganza
description: Music is the key to a summertime experience for pros and amateurs called the DiscOasis in Central Park. Its curator: the funk-disco guru and lifelong skater Nile Rodgers.
content: To some people, a roller rink is just a place to skim around in a circle, not even very fast, going nowhere. But to its devotees and to the creators of the DiscOasis, a new skate experience in Central Park, it is transformational, spiritual — time travel on four wheels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Why Does Israel Have So Many Elections?
description: Israelis are heading back to the polls for the fifth time in under four years.
content: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Naftali Bennett of Israel is moving in the coming days to dissolve Parliament and bring down his own government a year after taking office, a process that will automatically trigger new elections within a few months. The dissolution bill has been scheduled for a preliminary vote on Wednesday, with a final vote coming most likely on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
title: Panel Ties Trump to Fake Elector Plan, Mapping His Attack on Democracy
description: The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack showed how the former president leaned on state officials to invalidate his defeat, opening them up to violent threats when they refused.
content: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack directly tied Donald J. Trump on Tuesday to a scheme to put forward fake slates of pro-Trump electors and presented fresh details on how the former president sought to bully, cajole and bluff his way into invalidating his 2020 defeat in states around the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Gronk Retires. Footballs Rejoice.
description: Tampa Bay tight end Rob Gronkowski announced his retirement in a social media post Tuesday.
content: Much to the relief of defensive coordinators, end zones and footballs — and to the dismay of party boats, keg suppliers and content aggregators — Rob Gronkowski announced Tuesday that he was (again) retiring from the N.F.L. This time, he means it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gardner
title: ‘Jersey Is Taking Over’: N.J. Hoopers Outshine the Shadow of New York
description: Far more N.B.A. players have come from New York than its neighbor state. But a wave of rising stars in boys’ basketball can shift the trend.
content: Elliot Cadeau was born in Brooklyn, but he doesn’t have any memories of living in the borough. When he was 3 months old, his parents packed up their possessions, strapped him into his car seat and decamped to New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: After Treatment Comes a New Battle, and Cancer Patients Aren’t Prepared
description: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Emerson Riter, age 15.
content: This essay, by Emerson Riter, age 15, from The Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s Ninth Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 16,664 entries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Naftali Bennett’s Exit Interview
description: Israel’s departing prime minister reflects on a government that tried to put pragmatism ahead of ideology.
content: No elected Israeli prime minister ever had a shorter tenure than Naftali Bennett. On Monday, after a string of parliamentary defections, he announced that he would dissolve Parliament and call new elections, Israel’s fifth since 2019, after serving barely a year in office. On Tuesday, he WhatsApp-ed me from Tel Aviv for a phone call about his record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Nordic Combined, One of the Oldest Winter Olympic Sports, Faces Elimination
description: Leaders of Nordic combined, a mix of cross-country skiing and ski jumping, thought they had secured the future of the sport. But the International Olympic Committee is skeptical.

author: By Sarah Moss
title: Children’s Stories for Adult Audiences
description: In the world of Hilary Mantel’s “Learning to Talk,” childhood can be a dangerous place.
content: Hilary Mantel’s short story collection “Learning to Talk” was first published in Britain in 2003, before long-overdue prizes and international fame came her way. It shares the qualities of the contemporary novels she wrote for 20 years: sharp observation, alertness to the tomfooleries of class and gender, an uncanny capacity for the child’s-eye view, a door always open to the supernatural. And like Mantel’s most famous books, these stories are dark and absurd, the piping children’s voices brewed in wisdom and worldliness.

title: When Antlers Tangle, Sometimes Both Animals Lose
description: Antlers, the headgear of deer, moose and elk, are more useful for display than combat. But that does not stop deadly lockups from occurring.
content: As the days of summer days pass, the antlers get longer on moose, elk and other animals in the cervid, or deer, family. The animals spend most of the summer grazing, their head weaponry sheathed in fuzzy velvet. But by the end of September, the antlers will be ready for action as male suitors gather to posture, preen and butt heads — a behavior that some people may have in mind when they use the phrase “locking horns.”

description: Build confidence in the kitchen with these delicious recipes.
content: We all have to start somewhere. That’s the inspiration behind this small but mighty collection of recipes for absolute beginners. We’re talking can-hardly-boil-water beginners. Maybe you just graduated from college and are on your own for the first time, or perhaps you never quite got the hang of cooking. Not to worry! These dishes — ranging from a no-cook tuna mayo rice bowl to oven-roasted chicken thighs with potatoes and lemons — are a fantastic place to start. Because no one wakes up one day and can suddenly, say, run a marathon or, in this case, cook.

description: Noughty, the maker of nonalcoholic sparkling wines, has added this red still made in South Africa to its lineup.
content: Noughty, the rather good nonalcoholic sparkling wines , made by Thomson & Scott of London, have been joined by the company’s new still red nonalcoholic pour (at less than .5 percent alcohol). Produced in South Africa from syrah grapes and a far cry from Hermitage, it’s still an acceptable quaff alongside burgers or kebabs off the grill. It will be excellent for sangria; serve it chilled. Though lacking much nose, it does deliver a grapy palate that is not sweet, has body and, what makes it distinctive, delivers a welcome touch of tannin.

content: Until recently, I’d thought of trees as tall, attractive sources of shade and occasional power outages. Trees, it turns out, are amazing!

content: China’s ambition to collect a staggering amount of personal data from everyday citizens is more expansive than previously known, a Times investigation has found. title: A Medieval Dramedy Sheathed in Magic, and the Absurd
description: Ottessa Moshfegh’s fifth novel, “Lapvona,” is set in a corrupt fiefdom plagued by drought, famine and, well, plague.
content: Lapvona is a minor fiefdom somewhere in medieval Europe. Its ruler, Lord Villiam, is a spoiled and petulant schemer, so feeble that when he walks down from his castle to the church in the village, he has to be carried back uphill. Lapvona was once a good place, with fertile soil and low taxes. Now, in the aftermath of a plague, it is grim, parched and poor. Its plight is worsened because Villiam has at his disposal a gang of bandits who periodically ransack the village, stealing crops for Villiam to secretly sell to his business contacts in another fiefdom up north. Lapvona is also squalid in all the familiar medieval ways: a place of pestilence, deformities and skin diseases, lurid crime and extreme punishment.
